qas.question: How are male chickens able to be identified ?

answers.text: cocks, are usually larger, more boldly coloured, and have more exaggerated plumage than females (hens).

qas.question: What do chickens normally consume when in the natural wild environment?

answers.text: in their natural surroundings search among the leaf litter for seeds, invertebrates, and other small animals.

qas.question: Do chickens fly like other birds?

answers.text: They seldom fly except as a result of perceived danger, preferring to run into the undergrowth if approached.

qas.question: From what birds are chickens decended from ?

answers.text: Today's domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is mainly descended from the wild red junglefowl of Asia

plausible_answers.text: seeds, invertebrates, and other small animals

plausible_answers.text: as a result of perceived danger, preferring to run into the undergrowth if approached

qas.question: Why are chickens unable to fly?
What birds are chickens superior to?
When did the domestication of chickens fail?

context: <b5_0>Chickens<b5_0/> are medium-sized, chunky birds with an upright stance and characterised by fleshy red combs and wattles on their heads. Males, known as <a0_0><a1_0><b6_0><b10_0>cocks<b10_0/><b6_0/><a0_0/>, are usually larger, more boldly coloured, and have more exaggerated plumage than females (hens).<a1_0/> Chickens are gregarious, omnivorous, ground-dwelling birds that <a2_0>in their natural surroundings search among the leaf litter for <b11_0>seeds, invertebrates, and other small animals<b11_0/>.<a2_0/> <a3_0>They seldom fly except <b12_0>as a result of perceived danger, preferring to run into the undergrowth if approached<b12_0/>.<a3_0/> <a4_0>Today's domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is mainly descended from the <b13_0>wild red junglefowl of Asia<b13_0/><a4_0/>, with some additional input from grey junglefowl. <b7_0>Domestication<b7_0/> is believed to have taken place <b14_0>between 7,000 and 10,000 years ago<b14_0/>, and what are thought to be <b8_0>fossilized chicken bones<b8_0/> have been found in northeastern China dated to around 5,400 BC. Archaeologists believe domestication was originally for the purpose of cockfighting, the male bird being a doughty fighter. By 4,000 years ago, chickens seem to have reached the <b9_0>Indus Valley<b9_0/> and 250 years later, they arrived in Egypt. They were still used for fighting and were regarded as symbols of fertility. The Romans used them in divination, and the Egyptians made a breakthrough when they learned the difficult technique of artificial incubation. Since then, the keeping of chickens has spread around the world for the production of food with the domestic fowl being a valuable source of both eggs and meat.
